description.narrative: Reduction in soil erosion

comment.narrative: More than 85 of land experiencing serious forms of erosion
At least half of the land under improved SLM registers at least 15 reduction in soil erosion by midterm and 40 cumulative by the end of the project

As noted earlier where farmers have adopted SLM practices mainly climate smart agriculture soil erosion has reduced by over 90 However across the entire focus area only a slight increase is noted in the soil erosion reduction at about 25 basing on the practices adopted and the level of practice In some cases farmers have reduced erosion using innovative technologies not originally promoted by the project for example using tree branches heaps and stone barriers to block water runoff

description.narrative: Change in soil fertility

comment.narrative: Very low and declining exact levels for pilot districts obtained during inception
At least 10 increase in soil fertility from baselines for land users consistently engaging in 35 improved practices by midterm and by 30 cumulatively by end of the project

According to biophysical studies done by NARO soil fertility on farmers land increased by 10 on average which also translated into increased crop production per unit area for farmers that adopted conservation agriculture practices particularly for maize and beans In addition through collaboration with Makerere University soil science department at least 12 farming communities acquired portable soil testing kits which provide guidance on soil fertility indicators thereby guide farmers to fertilize their land accordingly However voluntary use of inorganic fertilizers is still low

Number of charcoal producers using improved kiln in carbonization in pilot districts increase by at least 30 by midterm and a cumulative 50 by project end

The number of charcoal producer groups using improved kilns in carbonization increased by 10 during the year bringing the total adopters to 25 of the original users of traditional earth kilns Two additional SAM1 Retorts were built within the year bringing the current total to 6 in the two districts which are in use At least 150 charcoal producers have access to and utilize the SAM1 retorts and 600 charcoal producers are using the Casamance kilns Some limitation in adoption of the more preferred casamance was associated with the weight which made them difficult to transport into the forested areas A modified casamance is under construction increasing hope that more adopters will be realized even after project end
